q0.question: How is electricity sold by one public organization to another accounted for in Scope 1 and 2 reporting?
q0.ground_truth: Seller reports Scope 1, buyer reports Scope 2
q0.answer: Organization C sells the remaining 95 MWh of electricity to Organization D, which is an end user. In this scenario, the emissions associated with the electricity sold to Organization D would be reported under Scope 2 by Organization D, as it consumes the purchased electricity in its own operations. However, the emissions associated with the T&D losses are reported under Scope 2 by Organization D only if it owns or controls the T&D system. If Organization C does not own or control the T&D system, the emissions from T&D losses would be included in Organization D's Scope 2 reporting.

Accounting for Indirect Emissions from Purchased Electricity
missions associated with the purchased electricity
that is consumed by the reporting organization are
reported in scope 2. Scope 2 only accounts for the
portion of the direct emissions from generating elec-
tricity that is actually consumed by the organization. An
organization that purchases electricity and transports it
in a T&D system that it owns or controls reports the
emissions associated with T&D losses under scope 2.

[Page 96, score: 0.801]
However, if the reporting organization owns or controls
the T&D system but generates (rather than purchases)
the electricity transmitted through its wires, the emis-
sions associated with T&D losses are not reported under
scope 2, as they would already be accounted for under
scope 1. This is the case when generation, transmission,
and distribution systems are vertically integrated and
owned or controlled by the same organization.

emission by that facility. (Note: this is not considered
“double counting” within an organization’s inventory
since scopes 2 and 3 are by definition indirect emissions,
constituting another organization’s direct scope 1).

q6.context:
[Page 13, score: 0.766]
Proportional scoring 
In some instances, responses are scored in proportion to the amount of data that is disclosed.  
This scoring approach is used in questions in which the amount of information reported may vary 
between responders. Proportional scoring incentivizes complete reporting on all rows disclosed, 
by awarding points in proportion to the amount of information provided in a table. Points may be

[Page 13, score: 0.761]
the highest score across all scoring levels. Each scoring level is assessed consecutively – for 
example, a row that achieves full Disclosure and Awareness points but zero Management points 
is considered to have a better score than a row that achieves partial Disclosure points and full 
Awareness points.  
Type of proportional scoring 
Scoring criteria 
Proportional scoring by the number of cells 
completed in a table. Only one row might 
be scored, or multiple rows might be 
scored.

of the Market 2016 report15, over $42bn of green bonds

bond market is investment grade (BBB rated or higher) 
and more than half of that is AAA rated.

about definitions and transparency. Which projects 
meet sufficiently ‘green’ standards? How can investors 
be sure that their funds will achieve impact?

to provide issuers with the key components required 
for listing on the green bond market.
